message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The irreversible inhibition of cyclooxygenase-1 and cyclooxygenase-2 suggests that the medication is aspirin. Indomethacin and celecoxib are reversible inhibitors of cyclooxygenase, and carbamazepine is an anticonvulsant medication. The symptoms suggest that the patient may have tension-type headaches.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the drug inhibiting both COX-1 and COX-2 by covalent acetylation suggests aspirin as the most likely medication prescribed. It’s important to note that aspirin is also used for its antithrombotic effects.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The drug that irreversibly inhibits cyclooxygenase-1 and cyclooxygenase-2 by covalent acetylation is aspirin. The recurrent headaches with dull, nonpulsating quality suggest tension-type headaches, which can be treated with aspirin. Indomethacin and celecoxib are nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs as well, but they do not irreversibly inhibit cyclooxygenase-1 and cyclooxygenase-2. Carbamazepine is an anticonvulsant and is typically used for treating seizures or trigeminal neuralgia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only aspirin irreversibly inhibits COX-1 and COX-2 by covalent acetylation. The patient’s symptoms are suggestive of tension headaches, and aspirin is commonly used for tension headaches.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Aspirin irreversibly inhibits COX-1 and COX-2 by covalent acetylation. This is why Aspirin has a long-lasting action compared to other NSAIDs. The symptoms are consistent with tension-type headaches, which can be treated with aspirin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the drug's mechanism of action suggests that the medication prescribed is Aspirin, which irreversibly inhibits cyclooxygenase-1 and cyclooxygenase-2 by covalent acetylation. Indomethacin and Celecoxib are non-selective and selective nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, respectively, that reversibly inhibit cyclooxygenase-1 and cyclooxygenase-2. Carbamazepine is an anticonvulsant drug used to treat seizures and neuropathic pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. As the medication irreversibly inhibits cyclooxygenase-1 and cyclooxygenase-2 by covalent acetylation, the most likely option is Aspirin, which irreversibly acetylates cyclooxygenase-1 and cyclooxygenase-2. Indomethacin, Celecoxib, and Carbamazepine have different mechanisms of action and are not known to irreversibly inhibit cyclooxygenase.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The medication described is aspirin, which irreversibly inhibits both cyclooxygenase-1 and cyclooxygenase-2 by covalent acetylation. Indomethacin also inhibits COX but is not described as irreversible. Celecoxib is a selective COX-2 inhibitor and carbamazepine is not used to treat headaches.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a tension-type headache, and the medication prescribed irreversibly inhibits cyclooxygenase-1 and cyclooxygenase-2 by covalent acetylation. Among the options, only Aspirin has this mechanism of action.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The drug description narrows down the options to aspirin, which irreversibly inhibits COX-1 and COX-2 through acetylation. Indomethacin and Celecoxib are NSAIDs that inhibit COX reversibly. Carbamazepine is an anticonvulsant and not used for headaches. The symptoms of dull, nonpulsating headaches without associated symptoms suggest tension-type headaches, which can be treated with aspirin.
